statement.tex: %text Find the intervals in which the function $f(x)$ given by $f(x) = x^3 + \dfrac{1}{x^3}, x\neq 0$ is (i) increasing (ii) decreasing %

step.context: %text \underline\text{What are the conditions} for a function to be increasing or decreasing in some interval $[a,b]$? %
%text Given Step 1, when will $f(x) = y = x^3 + \dfrac{1}{x^3}$ be increasing and decreasing? %
%text Given Step 2, in \underline\text{which intervals} would $f(x)$ be increasing and decreasing? %
step.reason:
\begin{align} x^6-1 &= (x^3)^2-1 = \underbrace{(x^3-1)\cdot (x^3+1) }_{a^2-b^2 = (a-b)\cdot (a+b), a = x^3, b = 1} \end{align} \\
%text
Now comes the \underline\text{slightly tricky part}. The roots of $x^3-1$ and $x^3+1$ are 1 and -1 respectively. Hence, we will split the number line at $x=-1$ and $x=1$, thus giving us the following three intervals.
%
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline & x\leq -1 & x\in(-1,1) & x\geq 1 \\ \hline x^3-1 & - & - & + \\ \hline x^3 + 1 & - & + & + \\ \hline x^6 - 1 & + & - & + \\ \hline \end{tabular}
%text
And we can see \underline\text{from the last row} of the table that %
\begin{align} x^6-1 &\geq 0\text{ when }x\leq -1\text{ or }x\geq 1 \\ &\implies \frac{dy}{dx} \geq 0\implies\text{increasing} \\ x^6-1 &\leq 0\text{ when }x\in (-1,1) \\ \implies \frac{dy}{dx} &\leq 0 \implies\text{decreasing} \end{align}

step.context: %text \textbf{Trick Question} If a function $y=C$ (a constant) is defined in $[a,b]$, then \underline\text{can we say the following}? %
step.reason:
%text For an \underline\text{increasing} function, $\frac{dy}{dx} \geq 0$. Similarly, for a \underline\text{decreasing} function, $\frac{dy}{dx}\leq 0$.
Note, that in both cases $\frac{dy}{dx} = 0$ is allowed.
It is only for \underline\text{strictly} increasing or decreasing functions that $\frac{dy}{dx}\neq 0$. %
